description:
Mmmm... this place definitely hits the spot for my dumpling cravings. From the shui Jian bao to the delicious red oil dumplings (don't know the exact names), the chewy texture of the dumpling skins and the savory fillings really made a Saturday lunch worth remembering. And coming back to. Again and again. 

Next time I'm in the city and craving dumplings, I'll be sure to hit up this spot.
author: S. H.

description:
My husband and I stopped by last night for dinner and we're so thrilled that this place is close to our new apartment!

The folks that run this restaurant are very kind especially the woman who seems to work in the kitchen and helps run food. While she doesn't speak English, she made sure our teapot stayed full and that we had everything we needed.

We order the beef wrap, pork dumplings in chili oil, black bean sauce noodles, XLB, and pan fried dumplings. The beef wrap and noodles were great! We also really liked the dumplings in oil (just the right level of spice and flavor) and pan fried dumplings (watch out - these guys were juicy AF). The XLB was fine for the price but it was the most average dish of the evening for us.

The total came out to be about $45 after tax and we had leftovers. I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Grace C.

description:
Just ordered delivery and everything is delicious! The dumplings are fresh and handmade. The hubby and I ordered a total of 10 items and they were all delicious! 

Chicken corn soup 

Cucumber with sauce: nice and garlicy just how I like it 

Sesame chicken : not oily at all but still flavorful

Chow fun: not greasy and full of flavor 

Shrimp fried rice, tofu and fermented egg, green onion pancake and dumplings hand made fresh and not frozen!! 

I'll definitely be back for more !!
author: Jami G.

description:
Met a friend for a late lunch here. Definitely worth a try a try! The secret is to order off the chef's specialty menu. The first thing I order is the XLB, if the restaurant has on their menu, then I proceed to see what appeals to me. We ordered their hand pulled noodles with braised beef and the twice cooked pork belly. The hand pulled noodles alone is worth the trip to this restaurant, if you have never experienced hand pulled noodles, it's definitely worth a try, you may get hooked like I have.  Then the twice cooked pork belly, this is not prepared the cantonese style with the persevered mustard greens, but braised in a dark soy in big chunks and served with shanghai bock choy. Yum and double yum!
For the price, I think the dishes were a little small, but due to food cost etc. that may be the norm now. I think the noodle dish could have been at least a little more substantial. All and all worth a try.
author: Raymond L.

description:
They're currently going under a reconstruction (aka no dim sum for now), but it seems like they updated their menu for the better.
I ordered an orange chicken (just chicken, no rice) and was expecting a brightish, syrupy sauce coating the chicken, but it was actually a sweet soy sauce based sauce with some sweet tang and some orange peels on the chicken. It might be (somewhat) healthier food now, but it was unexpected, in a good way. You still get the sweet notes (with tang from the orange peel), but there's an extra layer of flavor to the crispy chicken now. I definitely suggest giving these revamped dishes a try.
author: Timmy C.

description:
This place is so much better than Shanghai Dumpling King was (permanently closed/sold from across the street). I'm saying so much better because the dumplings and noodles are all made with dough kneaded by hand and ingredients are fresh. Textures were just right: fluffy and chewy for dumplings, crispy but soft for beef wrap. We ordered (whimsically) beef wraps for appetizer, dumplings per craving, and eggplant for some veggie relief.

Side note: Not sure why this is classified as a Szechuan Chinese restaurant on Yelp - it's clearly stated Beijing style on the windows of the restaurant - but Szechuan styles sound trendier. Beijing and northern Chinese cooking is what you want in a dumpling or noodle house. These were the traditional staple foods for northern Chinese.
author: S J.

description:
If you look at a map of China you'll notice it's a massive country, with numerous geographic regions, each with their own cuisine. Believe it or not, you can subdivide those regions even further into an almost innumerable variety of regional cuisines. It's where two regions (and their unique cultures) overlap that you find some of the most magical food.

We came to the Richmond in search of Shanghainese food, and we found an even more specific variation of that cuisine, with influences of the Muslim culture from the western part of China, here at Village House. 

As with most great Chinese eats in the US, you've gotta look past the recognizable items on the menu and dig to uncover the unique specialties of the house. I've gotten to the point where I can trust my gut (literally and figuratively) and we selected several dishes that let the true regionality shine including: 
Shredded Pork with Bean Curd Skin, Ro Ja Moa (aka Chinese "Hamburger"), Cumin Lamb, Hot and Sour Potato, Chao Bing (stir fried shredded pancake with beef and bean sprouts), AND hand folded lamb and zucchini dumplings. 

Hard to pick a favorite from that lineup because they all had their own unique merits, but I think I fell in love with the dish that sounds the simplest... hot and sour potato. Chinese chefs are masterful with their cleaver, and to julienne a potato by hand is no small feat. The uniformity in the cutting and cooking was truly impressive, and the sour and spicy sauce made this simple dish a beautiful marriage of flavor and texture that perfectly interrupted some of the richer dishes on the table. 

I'd have to say my second favorite was the shredded pork with bean curd skin. The shredded pork is coated in a glistening sweet sauce and set atop a pile of sliced cucumbers and bean sprouts, garnished with fresh cilantro and surrounded by squares of bean curd skin. As with many Chinese dishes, elements combine flavors and textures for the perfect bite, and in this one, the pork is so tender delicate that the bean curd adds in the chew while the veggies add in some freshness. 

Lastly, you can't help but notice the prep area dedicated to dumplings here. These aren't the intricate Cantonese dim sum dumplings you might've enjoyed elsewhere, but rather these are simple, handmade, and comforting dumplings, quickly boiled and served with black vinegar for dipping. They seem to make them by the bushel, almost to order, and you should absolutely try them when you're here.

If you're unfamiliar with this cuisine, I'd suggest repeating our order because it really hits some high notes. We were a party of three and ordered enough food for six, and yet our bill was still only $30/pp with tax and tip. I craved these flavors for the next few days. Absolutely delicious, unique, and impressively affordable.
author: Michael T.

description: This place has 4 Star review but honestly It didn't wow me. The only thing I would come here for is their fresh pulled noodles but that's all. The pig ear had a weird soapy taste to it which we both didn't like. XLB is just ok and I thought the soup was good but nothing wow. The black bean noodle flavor isn't good but we love the fresh pulled noodle. The noodle was nice and chewy. Overall just 3 Star. Service was ok too. I Feel bad for the worker. He did everything while I assumed the owner and two others behind the counter didn't help when busy. The owner boss him around while he stand and watch him work even when busy. Overall even with the worker treatment I can see they try to give good service. The price is reasonable too.
author: Christy V.

description: ***One of the best places for quick, inexpensive and delicious Chinese snack/dim sum dishes.*** Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs. The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu. Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.
author: Sterling C.

description: This place is delicious! Probably the best family-style Chinese that I've had in the area. Would 100% recommend to anyone :)
author: Austin S.

description:
The dumplings here are the bomb, you can't go wrong with the dumplings you get! Our personal favs are the pork & cabbage, soups dumplings & the potstickers. Add some Honey walnut prawns & shrimp chow mein to throw a little seafood in the mix. Pork buns are tasty but have a little too much "bun" to it. If you don't have a preference, order it. The pork is really good! 

It's also the first place I've seen hot & sour soup with cilantro in it... the soup wasn't bad but it wasn't good. The cilantro was just too much and gave the soup an interesting flavor.
author: Angella G.

description:
Delicious food. Excellent service. Super kind and sweet owner. I never noticed this place although I live in this neighborhood. My bf and I finished watching a movie at the Balboa theater and wanted to get a bite to eat. We walked around for a bit and found this restaurant. And what a gem this place is! 

They have a few new dishes or specials written on a wipe board so I asked the waiter which was is his favorite among them. He said it was the sweet and sour fish so I went with that. The dish was much larger than what me and my BF expected, and we ate much more than expected (we ate the whole thing). The fish was so good that I wanted to get another order to-go so my mom can try it for dinner, and also so I can eat more of it =P. The shanghai dumplings were really good too! I added another of that to-go as well. The owner was so sweet that he added another fish with my order. He seemed so happy that we enjoyed our food (well, the food was amazing so that's easy). 

I think I just found my favorite chinese restaurant and my to go spot. I'll be back! A lot. :)
author: Betty L.

description:
Came here after wandering the Marin headlands looking for something quick and delicious. It was a pleasant surprise. 

We ordered hot and sour soup, soup dumplings, and pan fried dumplings.

Hot and sour soup:
Very traditional hot and sour soup. My partner was little skeptical at first because his only experience was Panda Express. He enjoyed it very much. I liked it because it was a great balance of a spicy vinegar flavor that helped my appetite. 

Soup dumplings:
These were ok, good flavor, but they were not very "soupy". I don't recommend, pan fried dumplings were more juicy. 

Pan fried dumplings:
THIS WAS FLAVORFUL AND JUICY. Get this!! I'm not going to review this. You just need to try it. 

SERVICE WAS GREAT, very fast.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Ordered delivery and the food was delicious. The spicy dumplings were my favorite dish we ordered. The broth of the beef braised soup was SO good too.
Only downside is the gentleman on the phone told us we needed a minimum to receive delivery service and so we added one dish then when I go to pay our total is WAY over the minimum and we felt tricked into ordering another dish we didn't need. Other than that, good food!
author: Anne G.

description:
I decided to order dinner early and was feeling Chinese. I thought I'd try a new place - boy what a mistake. I put in my order, turned on the tv and waited for my order to come. I waited and waited and waited. Then 1.5 hours later I called the restaurant and asked if the food was on the way. The guy said well the food is ready just need a delivery guy - WTF! 

The restaurant then asked if I could just wait a little longer. Needless to say I never got my food and had to wait yet another hour to get something else.
author: Angelito R.

description: Village House is wonderful. Delicious, super flavorful xiao long bao -- probably the best I've had in the city -- as well as really tasty noodle dishes and scallion pancakes. It wasn't too crowded when I went so it's a great spot for a weekend brunch on the way to Golden Gate Park or wherever your day takes you!
author: Simone R.

description:
My mom and I were craving for some noodles and dumplings, so we went on yelp to look up some places. We went to two places and they were both closed or closing soon. That's when we stumbled upon Village House. 

When we entered, we were immediately greeted and then seated with menus and tea. The place was small and quaint. The menu was pretty large, but we had our heart set on dumplings and noodles. So we ordered xiao long bao and beef stew. 

Overall, we enjoyed the food. I would order the xiao long bao again, if I ever came back. The beef stew was good, but could use more flavor and spice. I would definitely come back to try more dishes l, if I was near the area. 

(*´`*)
author: Krystal H.

description:
Meh - I think this restaurant at best. I wasn't super blown away by any of the items I ordered and would go to another Asian restaurant next time

Beef roll - just okay, meat was a little flavorless, maybe a little old... 
Beijing noodles - super disappointed in this. It was sloppily made - noodles overcooked so when you ate it with the sauce, there's no chew to the noodles and makes the sauce too wet. 
XLB -  this was pretty good actually. I'd order this again. I wished there was more soup and filling though but the skin was good. 
Fish flavored eggplant - Pretty decent taste though a little too greasy. Still okay. 

Waitress was nice and gave us a free red bean cake. It seemed a bit old. I'd suggest frying these fresh because time does make a big difference!
author: Cindy W.

description: We were craving some good XLB and found the sweetest new spot. We had 4 big dishes, sat and took our time, and walked out of there for $45 (that includes a $10 tip). Why the big tip? The waiter might be my new favorite person. Super attentive, helpful with some suggestions, and very funny. The atmosphere is warm, the food comes out quick. Plates are for sharing, 4 medium hungry people or 2 very hungry people could have had what the two of us shared last night. If anything could improve, I'd say the soup dumplings weren't as soupy as I'd have liked. 2/3 of the ones I ate had leaked already by the time I picked them up. The flavor was great though. We'll definitely come back!
author: Jenny M.

description:
A really funny place. 

The waiter is authentically awkward: no smile, spilling stuff on the table and not wiping it off for about 10 minutes. Although in the context of this place, it was rather comforting. 
Interior: absolute hole in the wall 
Nevertheless, food is 4.5 and beware the size of portions, one soup can easily feed a family of 4.
author: Misha S.

description: Nice chewy house made noodles and wonderful beef broth. Service was a little slow and we overheard an argument in the kitchen about some takeout orders getting mixed up so the whole dinner experience had a side of anxiety. Overall we liked how everything we ordered seemed to be made with care despite the kitchen hiccups. Will return!
author: Tracy G.

description: I came here with 2 other friends at 1:30 pm after hiking around Land's End on Saturday. It's a very close drive from Land's End, and we only waited 15 minutes. The chef was very friendly and recommended some good dishes for us. I really liked the pan fried pork buns, red oil dumplings, fennel dumplings, cumin beef spareribs, and onion pancake. I will definitely be coming back here when I'm in the neighborhoods again.
author: Tiffany S.

description: Delicious, reasonably-priced and fresh Chinese food! Very nice owner. We had the Hot and Sour Soup, Beef Chow Fun, Pork Buns and General's Chicken and everything was superb! Definitely will be back. Great little neighborhood family business.
author: Sara J.

description: Excellent food, excellent service. I came here after a round of golf and got the xiao long bao, pig ears, and beef noodle soup. All were fantastic...great tea too (for free).
author: Jimmy D.

description: Delicious food with very unique and authentic menu items. The staff was very attentive and recommended things on the menu. We ordered hot and sour soup, stir fry green beans, pork bun, and pork dumplings! Everything was delicious and we even had left overs. Will recommend to anyone looking for good Shanghainese food. We will definitely be visiting again.
author: Neda P.

description: Excellent unassuming and delicious! Dumplings are made from scratch with fresh dough and you can taste it! I regularly get XLB and Spicy Dumplings, their noodle dishes are delicious as well and their more "american" style selections are also some of the best I've had in the area.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Every dish here was so incredibly delicious!

We got the eggplant, chili lamb, spicy dumplings, XLB and beef noodle soup. I couldn't believe the 3 of us almost finished all of it, but it was so good that there was barely anything left!
author: Sara M.

description:
Food is delicious!! My brothers and I come here few times a week for lunch. Every dish was impressive with excellent quality with tasty flavors...

Portions are big! 

Prices are reasonable so this is another reason why we go all the time. It's like $8-10 for a dish! 
Credit card minimum $20. The owner is really nice. 

Our favorites are:
Chicken Cashew
Cold Noodle with cucumbers 
Braised Eggplant
author: Jennifer S.

description: Beijing hand made dumpling and noodles. Great service! Very reasonable prices. My friend and I ordered the braised beef noodle soup, spicy dumplings, xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and garlic bok choy. Everything made fresh from scratch. Even the garlic was freshly shaved. Really good! Give them a try.
author: Aaron W.

description: This place had such great service, understaffed but they tried their best! The dumplings are amazing and the price is so cheap! What a steal!!!! Definitely coming back again!
author: Yadira D.

description:
Yeah, this place is a FIND. Tucked in the Outer Richmond, Village House has an unassuming exterior, but delicious food. We got the following three dishes (and would be hard-pressed not to get them again):

- Spicy Fish Soup with Pickled Cucumbers
- Stuffed Onion Pancake
- Vegetarian Dumplings (Fried)

The waiter was funny, and the chef came out to make sure we enjoyed the food. The three dishes meshed really well together, and we also got some white rice. The prices were reasonable for the city, and the spice level was perfect for our mild palettes. The menu has a lot of dishes I have not seen at other SF Chinese restaurants.
author: Marcel M.

description: Great homemade/hand crafted dumplings with a variety of different styles and fillings.  Excellent Beef Chow Fun.  Great, friendly service, and reasonably priced. Also, the food was made to order and very fresh right in the dining room. Highly recommended. Thank you!
author: Bryan E.

description: Village House has delicious food. Their service and yummy meals paired for a great combination. I would definitely return here for the fun atmosphere!! A little quiet but a nice escape from the hustle and bustle. 10/10
author: Noreen C.

description:
super great food and service.
Prices fair.
author: Adam G.

description: The food here is authentic and the service is great. They guy led us to the table and was very attentive. The food came out fast and each dish was extremely flavorful. Thanks :)
author: Gloria Z.

description:
Found this place while I was taking my parents out around town. They came to visit from LA and we wanted lunch after wandering around the Legion of Honor and Land's End. I wanted the beef noodle soup we saw in the window, and we also ordered the chives pancake, the 生煎包, and dumplings with cabbage and pork, I think. The dumplings had thin skin and were pleasantly tender. My mom mentioned how the dough for the 生煎包 was soft without sticking to the teeth and the bottoms were browned without being burnt. The soup for the noodle soup was flavorful and everything came out piping hot which was great given the chill outside.

The waiter was great and attentive and I'd totally take friends here in the future.
author: Nicole Y.

description:
Food is great! Their dumplings, Liang'Pi, spicy lamb, pork with tofu skins are very tasty.  

The service is great too! Waiter kept adding water and tea for us throughout the entire dinner. 

Overall it was a great dinning experience. It would be really cool if they have more dishes on the menu for selection.
author: Nicky G.

description: Food was good, service was terrible. We came in about 2:15 on a Saturday. There was only one gentleman seating people and taking orders. Speak quickly and ask for every thing the first time he takes your order, because if you want water or rice or a fork you will not see him again. Again, terrible service.
author: McKay B.

description: All the food was fantastic, service was fast, and the waiter was very friendly and helpful. yum!!
author: Chai T.

description: Update: they now have Liang Pi 涼皮 a Xian/Shaaxi regional specialty or "cold skin" starch noodle w/ seitan aka wheat gluten, cucumber, scallion, cilantro, sesame & peanuts in a tangy spicy vinegary dressing. One of my favorite noodle dishes done really well! They call it Special Cold Noodle on their new menu.
author: Ramon W.

description: Xiao long bao = 11/10. Also delicious vegetables and chow fun. Great service, exactly the right place to be all the time. Please go here and listen to the recs of the wait staff!
author: Stephanie S.

description: We actually were trying to go to shanghai house ended up coming to village house for our first time. The food was absolutely amazing and our waiter was kind, friendly, and made great recommendations. We would definitely go back!
author: T S.

description:
Horrible customer service! I loved previous place Jook Time for quick dim sum takeout. Decided to give new place a try. Sign on window said 'Potstickers $5'. Asked for potstickers in Cantonese & Mandarin. Both lady & man looked puzzled. Pointed to potstickers on counter. Man said $7.60 but he doesn't have change for my $20. What kind of business does not have change? I asked why they have a sign outside for $5. The man pulls out menu & tells me it is $7 not $5. He told me it was for a promotional 4 potstickers. That's all I wanted but no one asked! He didn't want to give me back my $20 and made me feel like it's my fault for ordering the 'Wrong' thing. I was so angry. I told a friend who has a business close by & he said he had an bad experience with the lady recently!
Too bad Village..I would've been coming here few times a week if food was good & if I was not treated that way
author: Jenny W.

description: Yummy food every time. Kind staff, newly decorated, card accepted. Take out is so easy, only takes about 15-20 minutes for your food to be ready. Chow mein is delicious, dumplings are good, garlic veggies (bok choy, spinach, etc) are the perfect side, and portion size is large. Often overlooked by shanghai dumpling king across the road, but is an equally, if not superior (gasp -- I know), meal.
author: Madeline M.

description: We came here seeing the overall good reviews and wanting some good dim sum, and they delivered! Very friendly wait staff and chefs, who were more than willing to accommodate our dietary needs. The dumplings were smaller than expected, but they come with enough to feel very satisfied, with two people we got two orders of dumplings and a side dish and were happily full. The complimentary tea was also very nice to have on a foggy evening! Will most def return! Keep in mind, it is a smaller restaurant so seating is limited.
author: Taylor L.

description:
I don't know how this place got 4 stars but maybe TODAY they weren't ready at all for customers. We're lucky we got there first (party of 5) because the back is the only place really that can accommodate more than 4 people. Otherwise the place is just too small. 

Anyway we ordered and everything else came EXCEPT the rice and mind you we already waited long for the food but we also had to eat really slow because we wanted our rice that came 10 million years later. The tea wasn't refilled and we had to ask for water that came lukewarm. 

The food is okay too so it's safe to say this is our first and last time here.
author: Gem C.

description:
Absolutely scrumptious! We ordered beef noodle soup, wonton noodle soup, spring rolls (the BEST spring rolls I have ever had: packed with veggies, not dry or over-fried, so tasty), shredded pork in wonton wrappers, and black bean noodles. Unbelievably happy with every single dish--the noodles are hand rolled and cut with a great texture, and the soups were incredibly flavorful. The bok choy dish was a huge hit too -- I don't know what they did to this classic veggie dish, but it was unbelievably tasty. Dessert = red bean pancakes, hot out of the oven, sweet and with heapings of red bean filling. 

Service was fast but not so fast that we felt rushed. Waitress and the chef (he came out to say hello and refill our tea) were so nice and welcoming. I will definitely be back with another large group! One of my new favorite restaurants in the Richmond for sure.
author: L T.

description: Food is great here. We got loads of the dumplings and fried noodles. All hit the spot for us. The Chinese burger taste great but I much prefer lamb as a filling. Overall good experience. But the waiter did not speak Chinese and had that serial killer feel to him- a little uncomfortable.
author: Jimmy C.

description: They kept rambling on about recommendations and miscommunicated with us about the items they were writing down on our order. They added a totally different item onto our order and removed something that we originally asked for. The item they listed on our order was nothing but 98% bone and 2% meat. They refused us a refund because they blamed us for "ordering that item" even when we did not ask for that in the first place. Horrible customer service and food wasn't even that great, my god. The prices were ridiculous as well.
author: Christine Y.

description: Excellent dinner tonight!! Our party of three shared the braised tofu, shredded potato + green pepper, and mixed veggies and we had enough to take home some leftovers! Everything was absolutely delicious and came out super fast even though the restaurant was packed. Our server was attentive and speedy as well as patient while we decided what we wanted. Would absolutely recommend and will definitely be back!!
author: Kat C.

description: We recently moved to the neighborhood, and I stopped by here for some quick dim sum at lunch. The proprietor/manager ("Clark"?) was very welcoming and attentive, bringing out hot tea while I looked at the menu. Ordered a pork bun and egg and tomato soup for lunch. The pork bun was hot, freshly made with lots of filling. The egg and tomato soup came a few minutes later, and although dangerously hot  at first, smelled delicious with noodles at just the right consistency. It stayed warm through to the end and I finished very satisfied and full. Would recommend during off hours, will have to check out again. Thanks!
author: Jay B.

description: My mother introduced this place to me and was excited when I heard the type of food that was offered. I'm normally a picky person when it comes to Chinese-style food but this place exceeded beyond my expectation! I enjoyed how everything was handmade from scratch, the dishes had their own unique flavors, and the different variety of dishes to choose from the menu. Overall, this family-owned restaurant allowed me to leave with a smile on my face. Service was great, food was great, I have now found my new favorite spot to eat!
author: Kiana S.

description: Very good chinese cooking and incredible prices. Our waiter was very pleasant and fast and we really enjoyed the food. They offer homemade dumplings and other wonderful chinese dishes. Thousand of dishes!
author: Conchi G.

description: An unexpected but wonderful experience! The restaurant is clean and the service is great. We ordered Sliced Beef in Chili Oil and Egg Fried Rice. They are both good and cooked in traditional Chinese way. We love them so much. Oh and the price is also good, not expensive. We will come again next time.
author: Tian X.

description: Best Chinese food, hands down. The food is incredibly fresh and delicious. Our waiter was a delight. My lunch was so good, I decided to order a few dishes to-go for dinner the same night! Will definitely be back soon.
author: Gaby L.

description: Great little place. Friendly staff. Freshly made  food. Great XLB! Would definitely come back again.
author: Adam S.

description: When folks visit us in SF, we bring them to Village House and they love it, too. Braised beef noodle soup, xiaolong bao, salt & pepper chix wings, spicy green beans, red bean dessert, all the dumplings... Omgosh you cannot go wrong with anything on the menu. Great prices, wonderful service; like home cooked comfort food. It's a hole in the wall. When we see  people pop their heads in then leave, we always think, "Too bad. You don't know what you're missing." Owner did a recent 'renovation' which is kind of cute as it now has tiny red lanterns hanging everywhere. It's midnight as I type this review and damnit, I want some dumplings...
author: M F.

description: I love this place! They're so nice and welcoming. The waiter was very patient and answered any question we had. We ordered the xiao long bao, wonton soup, stir fry noodles, and pan fried noodles! All very delicious. The portion sizes were really good with cheap prices! Would definitely come back.
author: Ngan V.

description: Very friendly staff! The food is wonderful and very cheap! The food comes out very fast and service is excellent !! I came in hungry and walk out very full and happy !!
author: Sandy C.

description: Came here to have brunch with friends, and have to admit the food was pretty good but some of the dishes were a bit too bland for my tastes. We had the XLB, beef roll, braised eggplant, and Beijing bean sauce noodles. The location is easy to get too but hard to find parking around especially on the weekend.
author: Vanessa S.

description: We happened upon this place because the restaurant we were looking for was closed. And we are so lucky it happened that way! We had the spicy dumplings, pan fried pork buns, and honey walnut prawns. They were all top notch and would highly recommend them all! The customer service can't be beat. I would give this 10 stars if I could!
author: Eric P.

description: These folk know Chinese food!  I love eating here.  Often I get their frozen steamed buns to go and cook them at home later.  I always feel good after a meal.
author: Austin C.

description:
Favorite Chinese restaurant. I am so glad i found this place. Food is fresh, fast, and delicious. Customer service is top notch. They want to make sure you have an enjoyable experience.

You must try the cold noodle dish. Its amazing.
author: Michael S.

description:
Super yummy food with really good service. 
The food is super cheap too! 
The server was seriously so gentle and nice, so I recommend  coming here for a good experience.
author: Monica O.

description: Great homemade dumplings for sale to take home to cook at a great value too!! Thanks!
author: Ploypailin A.

description: Food was really good. Service was very attentive. Another dumpling place within walking distance.
author: Hang N.

description: Best service. Best food. Try the pork buns. Wish I could live at this restaurant.
author: Ari C.

description: The waiter gave us excellent service. The soup dumplings were juicy and thin skinned. Highly recommend the sliced beef in chili oil.
author: Emma R.

description: The staff is really nice and the food reminds me of good home cooking! Try the garlic bok choy!
author: Janzen A.

description: Wow! Such great noodles. House made noodles with the perfect consistency...so good.  I was in the neighborhood looking for some tasty food and village house hit the spot. I also had a bbq pork bun that was super yummy.  Not only are the people who work here super nice, but the value for price can't be beat.  I'll be be back to try more menu item.  Highly recommend.
author: Meg F.

description: Nice little restaurant.  Don't come here if you want fancy dishes, they only have basic chinese foods like dumplings and noodles, but they do it well. Pretty tasty.
author: Megan M.

description: I wish I could give this place six stars. Our server was incredibly polite and gracious. I think probably the best service I have ever received in the city. And the Xiao long bao was so super good, I wanted to cry !
author: Hani S.

description: Great service and tasty dumplings and eggplant after a race. The food came out quickly and the host was really friendly and helpful
author: Vy N.

description: Great mom and pop place!  The Xiao long bao were yummy.  Dumplings weren't too thick and the filling was delish.  Can't beat the price either.  Also tried the shredded potato w vinegar and it was surprisingly good ... a mix of potatoes bell peppers and dried peppers, definitely had a little kick.  You can also watch them prepare the dumplings!
author: Tom K.

description:
My family first time here and we all wanted to tried this place since it has good review and 4 stars on yelp. Hey. Not bad at all. You should choose varieties of food and try them. That's what we did. 
Awesome!!!!!Our waiter sure kept our tea cups full. Wow... what a service!!!!!
For the service and food.. hey we'll come back again and try to eat different food next time from the menu.
author: Aron Y.

description: I. LOVED. This place. I am often hard pressed to find an authentic, low-key, actually high quality Chinese restaurant and this hit all the marks. First, the food was delicious, fresh, and satisfying. I had to black bean sauce dish with thick (handmade) noodles and fresh cucumber and carrot, it was similar to Korean jajang but lighter yet savory. We also had some pork buns and dumplings, also fresh and perfect. The server was polite as hell. And even joked with us and had a sense of humor. The place was also airy and light, the decor was cute. And the green tea was good. Totally want to go back.
author: Elan S.

description: Popped in here randomly en route to the Legion of Honor, and it was wonderful!  The staff was friendly & helpful.  (They really look out for vegetarians & any personal allergies, when you make it clear what you need.  I appreciate that so much!!)  The menu is clear & easy to understand (photos! yes!).  The flour drop soup was made vegetarian for me, very kindly.  It was overflowing & flavorful.  The red bean bun hit the spot, as I wanted to munch on something sweet.  It was all fresh and delicious.  I can't wait to try more of their menu.  Thank you, Village House!
author: Lani C.

description: Great place for handmade noodles. The broth is so flavorful. The noodles have the right texture.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Went here for lunch today after strolling Lands End since the nearby Shanghai places all had long waits and I figured the positive Yelp review meant something.  We ordered an assortment of dishes (boiled dumplings, beef noodle soup that had tasty "handmade" noodles but barely any beef, green onion pancake that was fantastic, Chinese hamburger which was a little odd with too much of the bun, green beans which were probably the highlight) that were all OK to pretty tasty, (except for the soup dumplings which were fairly meh with 5 out of 6 dumplings not having any soup in them and the skin being really thick).

The service was friendly and quick but what threw me off was at the end, the waiter came by and asked for our table to all give 5-star Yelp reviews and return we'd get 10% off our check.  The Yelp check-in already gives 10% off and I don't like the feeling of a business trying to "buy" my rating.  Minus one star for that shadiness - I think a much better approach would have been to let us know that they are a newer establishment and ask us to review them on Yelp - I would have happily rated them 4 stars even without the discount.  So if you see 5-star reviews here that are super short (and could have been typed out on a mobile phone), chances are they could have been bribed :-/
author: Mengo Z.

description:
+Boiled fish with pickles
+ pancake
+ house made hot sauce 

Great service here very attentive to what we were looking for. Will come again to try the dumplings. Thanks Village House!
author: Thomas L.

description: Excellent addition to the neighborhood and already much better than the previous restaurant.  Service was impressive this evening and displayed a humble charm. Food was delicious and excited about the next visit.
author: Stephen K.

description: Ordered takeout from Village House. The food was ready quickly and was very yummy. Will likely order food from here again.
author: Ruby H.

description: Very well made handmade chinese pancakes - more like bread than cake. Onion bread is the best plus the beef rolls are good too except the sauce is a bit too sweet for my taste. The delivery is a a bit late but the delivery person was friendly and polite.
author: SJ L.

description: This was our first time here and our experience was absolutely amazing. The customer service was out of this world. Our server was friendly and funny and engaged us perfectly and always made sure we had enough water or tea. The soup dumplings were phenomenal; perfect amount of soup and the dough was perfectly thin. My favorite dish was the Sliced Beef in Chili Oil - words can not describe this dish, just perfect. I would recommend this place to anyone.
author: Bryan K.

description:
I live nearby and was curious about this place, so I came by to order some takeaway. 

The lady working at the counter was very nice and I took a walk while my food was prepared, but got cold and came back in to wait. She saw that I was cold and brought some hot tea for me to drink while I waited. I was very impressed by the gesture.

The food was excellent, too. The sesame chicken and veggie chow mein were my favorite. There were no survivors (leftovers).  Plus the price was very reasonable. I'll definitely be back. Yay for another solid restaurant on Balboa!
author: Tatiana T.

description: I would give this place three stars. The advantage of this place is that they take reservations however don't expect to be seated right away. The food is pretty good but the service needs a lot of help. Also, don't preorder the smoked duck or the beef meatballs. They are overpriced and not so good. The Dumplings, noodles and pan cakes are very good. Lastly, don't expect your food to come all at the same time.
author: Helen L.

description: Great neighborhood option wide range of Chinese style foods.  Handmade dumplings and chow fun noodles were well flavored and balanced.  Friendly staff too.
author: Hotung T.

description: Great spicy dumplings and beef rolls. Their garlic pork belly was so good! It was small, cozy, and clean. Perfect for a a short lunch and anyone craving good authentic Chinese Food.
author: Isabella L.

description: Great place for some Chinese food. We only tried a few dishes but their stir fried sticky rice cake is phenomenal. Definitely coming back.
author: Jonathan H.

description: Came in at lunch on a Saturday & ordered the Xiao Long Bao with some General Chicken - both absolutely delicious. I only give 4 stars because it took 20 minutes to get the check when the restaurant was not busy so the service needs some work.
author: Sarah C.

description: I feel this place is a hit or miss. Sometimes we order to go and good would taste great and well balanced of flavors. At other times, things are either too salty, too bland, or too spicy. What I like is their boiled fish with szhuan pickles (suggest getting mild, it's pretty spicy) and their seafood fried noodles. Do not get the soy milk. It's watered down and tastes like artificial milk. We had to toss the 2 cups we ordered. Overall, I can't say they are bad, but again it's not always consistent.
author: Amy T.

description: You won't regret it! Great service and food isn't greasy even for fried food which I appreciate! Will definitely be back
author: Emily X.

description:
Village House takes over Jook Time with a potpourri of  northern chinese dishes. xiaolungbao, noodles, chow mein, soups, entrees, dim sum, dumplings.

dim sum counter mostly barren by 11:30, students arrived like locusts, buying up the already prepped chow meat, rice dishes, dumplings, (no prices seen)

eats: XO beef chow fun(6.95)
-dish too hot to eat immediaely, lots of tender beef slices,  flavor not traditional XO, a mix  of  soy, Xo, and msg? good portion, good value
-most entrees priced 6,99
3.5 stars

take aways:
--hard to find legal, non-meter parking
-student crowd a distraction to eating in at lunch.
-food's a good value here, not sure about quality.
just a timid 4 stars for possible fab tasting food at reasonable pricing.
*beware of baby kids running around, only distraction....
author: Victor G.

description:
I like this Quant 10 month newbie.  Nice to go post opening.  Local regulars were in the mix on a Saturday afternoon.  Glad I picked up the menu to absorb it's eclectic and enticing Beijing style cuisine.  Altho many Asian eateries along Balboa.  This is located in a unhurried environment.  Kinda.

So I sat down to Andrea's librarian and intellectual but curious smile.  Was she thinking of me staying? I did.  So I just went exotic and old school native The City boy.  I was welcome to use my personal thermos cup for tea.  No need to b Ave t b email was another pot.  Let what looked like her mom & dad curious to hear a local born voice with a nowhere accent.  Lol

Order:  Cold chilled julienne cut pig ears in a just right at jus.  
3.5-4   stars
             
Tomato beef chow mein, off the menu. 3.5-4  stars

 Why you ask off the menu?  Well being concierge back in the day.  It shows their ability to prepare at a moments nice.  Very key in hospitality.
So one great feature of there diverse kitchen.  They make their own noodles.   
Check it out!
author: Jim M.

description: This place is terrible! The food looked pretty bad when I went in but I got some pot stickers because I was starving.  The cost was $4 for 3 pot stickers! It was pretty pricy but again I was starving.  Before handing them over the lady asked if I wanted them microwaved because they were cold.  I just grabbed them and left after paying for them. They were not only cold, but also pretty gross.  I will never go back here again.  Such a shame because I live blocks away.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Playing Muni Roulette on Market Street yesterday, I decided to jump on the 31 Balboa to check out Village House (鄉村风味). I was probably drawn there by the fact thaat a Yelper had mentioned a "Chinese hamburger" and (correctly) assumed it was a roujiamo, but since it was past 5:00 when I got there I decided to make that the appetizer to  an early dinner. The young woman server was eager to promote the house-made xiaolong bao, dumplings (jiaozi) and noodles, so I ordered a basket of XLB and a lamb dumpling and noodle soup as my mains.

The roujiamo ("Chinese Hamberger" on the menu) was on the small side, but heck, it cost all of  $2.95. The panbread bun was about the right thickness, browned but not greasy, though a bit less dense than some versions. The meat filling was appropriately porky and salty in flavor, though the texture seemed wrong because  it was coarsely chopped (loin?) instead of stewed, so the sandwich was a bit dry as well.

I don't know if they knew what they were getting into, boasting about their house-made xiaolong bao in earshot of both Shanghai Dumpling King and Shanghai House, but they didn't embarrass themselves.  Their XLB is probably better than the last I had at SDK, but not quite as good as I remember Shanghai House's to be (though I haven't been to either of these places in a long time). The wrappers were delicate, and the soup ample, though they need to push the needle away from the salty side of the dial a bit toward the sweet side. But then, those were Beijingese voices floating around the room, not Shanghainese.

The soup was hearty, with six lamb dumplings and a long ton of noodles.  The dumplings were meaty but not particularly lamb-y (but I'd like try them again, outside of soup, to be fair). The noodles were springy and fresh, if not hand pulled. The broth seemed under-seasoned, particularly lacking salt, of all things. Since there was no salt shaker of the condiment tray, I used a bit of soy sauce along with chili paste to sex it up.

The menu contains a lot that will be of interest to fans of Northern Chinese style "dim sum." Chao bing was mentioned by a previous reviewer (in fact Village House has four versions), and they also have such relative rarities as sweet and savory shao bing (saobing), jian bing guozi, ji dan guan bing and doufu nao (which I'll definitely be back soon to try). In addition to other, more familiar  Northern Chinese fare, Village House's menu is augmented with a smattering of Shandong, Shanghainese, Xi'an, Sichuan and Xinjiang offerings.
author: Gary S.

description:
This is an unassuming Chinese restaurant on the edge off 35th and balboa in San Francisco. 
Don't be fooled by the average at best decor!  This has the best veggie Chinese food i have had in the Bay area!  Order the general's spicy chicken and broccoli,  substitute tofu . What you will get is crispy tofu, soft and buttery on the inside in a sweet, spicy sauce that is a bullseye. Szechuan perfection.
Only a family restaurant will make consistently good food.  THEY CARE.
author: Allan Ajaya D.

description:
Small but mighty good!
Across the street from the other Shanghai dumpling restaurant---offering superior dumplings and hand pulled noodles and other really delicious dishes.  The cook here takes care in the preparation and it totally shows!!
author: J G.

description: We always come to this cute little place on the corner and get Braised Eggplant and they have really good Northeast China style homemade dumplings with cabbage, pork, lamb, etc
author: Nongnaphat Y.

description:
I popped in on the weekend to buy some xiao long bao. The lady at the counter was rolling out the dough for potstickers.  She said since she's the only one making the food, she hasn't gotten to the xiao long bao yet.  

So I bought some potstickers.  They were sitting on the same counter.  It was nicely seared on the bottom but smaller than Jook Time's.  It was also more expensive.  I paid $7 for 8 dumpings.

I took it home and steamed it up and it was good.  There was a bit of soup or sauce inside so the meat wasn't hard and dry.

Another time, we dined in and ordered the green onion pancake and potstickers.  Pancake was ok.  However, they served us cold potstickers from the tray.  We asked them to heat it up and they over nuked it because then the skin was tough and hard.  I really think they should turn on the old Jook Time steam table or learn how to use the microwave. 

Service is friendly.

For now, I recommend take out only.  That way you can properly nuke the food yourself!
author: Wendy H.

description:
I ordered food from eat24 and waited for 2 hours. Msg support and support could get through to the restaurant. They never made the order.

Worst service ever. Would not recommend this place to anyone. Food might be good or decent but I'll never know.
author: Clifford H.

description:
So as it would have it, we actually live in the apartment on top of Village house.  I was very fond of Jook Time and all of their staff, they were very literally our neighbors.  While we miss them dearly, we've come to love Village House the same way.

They had a bit of a shaky start, and could probably improve a bit with their staff's attention to customers, but it's such a small restaurant that waving someone down is not a problem.

Everything I've had to eat there has been fantastic, (and I'd suggest the spring rolls because they're some of the best I've had.)

Village house is one of the few new places in this neighborhood that actually feels like a family business environment (Chino's would probably be my next suggestion!).  The staff and family running it are a joy, including their daughter who is possibly one of the best behaved kids I've ever seen.

I'm always going to miss Jook Time and it's staff (we love you!) but if you want a nice relaxed family environment with good food, kind staff, and reasonable prices I would definitely suggest Village House.  

They're only getting better over time, I can't wait to see how this place grows!
author: Cockatrice King I.

description:
it is pretty great having a northern style dumpling and pancakes Chinese restaurant in our neighborhood.  The best part is there is no line like at my other favorite House of Pancakes.  
Great dumplngs, buns, 炒餠 (chao bing stir fried dough strips), "burgers" and noodles.  Can't speak for the mandarin side of the menu.  They also have great red been pastries on the weekends too.   You can buy the dumplings frozen as well. 
Hopefully it will get a little bit more business as I am concerned they aren't doing enough to survive.  So come give it a try! Ask for recommendations if you don't know what you are doing as it would be sad to have this place get bad reviews for its cashew chicken or whatever other mandarin food you might be used to.
author: howard t.

description: Some of the best chinese food I've ever had. Every dish was perfect. The portions were very generous. The service was amazing. Loved it!
author: Julie C.

description: Love this place!! Every time I go here the service is great and the waiter is really nice. I really like the beef rolls  and the pork dumplings with green chives. 5/5
author: Claire G.

description: I live super close to Village House and just never made it in until today for lunch. It was raining and cold and it I was Ted something to warm me up. It was not busy but there was a woman making dumplings at the counter. The staff very friendly and the food is great. I recommend coming with friends and sharing several dishes. The hardest thing for me was settling on one dish. Super fresh and flavorful ingredients and perfectlt prepared. Don't let the fact that they might not have any customers in the place when you arrive. The food and service will be top notch.
author: Mischa H.

description: Food had a yummy, light taste. Not too oily or greasy so that was good. Portions were small compared to other restaurants in the area. The main problem is they put small amounts of chicken and beef. They need to put more meat in the dishes, not just vegetables. Prices on the menu were high. Parking is hard to find in the area. They make their noodles fresh in the kitchen. Bathroom was clean but dark. Overall, not bad and I will probably return.
author: Kev N.

description: Great homemade food and excellent service. The chef gave our kids hugs. They were kind to our "active" 4 year old. We'll be back for sure.
author: Anna R.

description: Very fresh, clean, delicious food! Had chicken and chive dumplings, Kung pao chicken, braised eggplant, and hot & sour soup. Service was very attentive and friendly. Great neighborhood spot!
author: Alex R.

description: Excellent staff. Good cheap food. Cute dining area. General Tsao's chicken was great. Many dumpling options
author: Anthony D.

description: We live in this neighborhood and enjoy this Chinese restaurant that serves both Cantonese and Mandarin dishes.  I've mainly eaten here for lunch while ordering noodle dishes (chow fun/chow mein) or soup dishes (beef noodle).  All of them were good and comparable to other Chinese restaurants I've been to and the prices are reasonable.  There is no complaints about the service as the same waiter is very attentive, constantly refilling my tea cup or making sure the hot water in my teapot is hot.  This is a small restaurant that seats at best (maximum 25 people).  At least for lunch, there is no waiting.  They also offer take-out and credit card charge is allowed only if  your bill is greater than $20.
author: cynthia n.

description: Was looking for a place to eat around the area and my girlfriend stumbled upon this restaurant on yelp so we decided to give it a try since they have handmade dumplings and noodles and I must say it was as good as we expected and it didn't disappoint at all. We ordered the egg with tomato noodle soup, the chicken and chive dumplings, the braised tofu, and the xiao long bao. Everything tasted great and was delicious. The service was also good. The waitress checked in on us asking if the food was good which was nice and one of the cooks who I think is the owner was even nice enough to come out and refill my tea. He even gave us a free sesame red bean pancake as a dessert. We're definitely coming back to try some of the other delicious looking food on their menu.
author: Gabriel H.

description:
Friendly, family run small neighborhood restaurant. Great trying Sichuan food here and Cantonese dishes too. Their large soup noodle bowls are yummy and perfectly satisfying  for those cold days! Especially enjoyed their preserved/pickled  vegetable dishes! Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes! Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?! So very good! Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.
author: E W.

description: This is an awesome place! I love the zang Jiang noodle and dumplings. Will definitely visit again
author: Vivian Y.

description: Cheap which is good but not good overall with the food. Dumplings and potstickers were actually solid but the steamed pork bun was hard as a rock and dry. Won't be coming back.
author: Alex R.

description: Best cold noodles, right amount of noodles, gluten, cucumber and sauce
author: Michael T.

description: Service was really friendly and overall it is a great value for the food. The Chinese hamburgers were different from what I had before but were really tasty!
author: Collin C.

description: Came here for lunch and we got the chicken chow Mein, xlb, pork and shrimp dumplings as well as the Mabo tofu. Overall everything was okay. Nothing spectacular honestly but I'd come back for a quick lunch if I was in the area
author: Diana N.

description: Family run, hand made noodles, and the food truly reminds me of the kinds of food my grandmother used to make. I order occasionally to go and every time its been fantastic especially their many noodle soups!
author: Killah K.

description:
One star for trying to pressure me into giving them a five star review.

Food was pretty good.  Service was inattentive.  There  was a cockroach under our table.
author: S G.

description: We ordered the xinjiang chicken. A huge dish, more than enough for two people. Taste great and good service.
author: Ray Z.

description: 30?  40?  50 times?  Yes, I've been here that many times since they opened about a year ago and not just because I live just six blocks away.  Lots of nearby restaurants, but this place is my favorite.  Spicy dumplings, I get these almost every time.  Xiao long bao is probably the best I've had anywhere in the city.  The soups are all excellent - I especially love the boiled fish with Sichuan pickles (perfect combination of spicy and sour) - and a side order of delicious hand-pulled noodles can be added to any of them.  And then there's the hot chili oil dishes - beef, lamb, or fish - these are amazing!  The oil is clean and perfectly spiced.  (We always take the extra oil home for cooking our own dishes.)  I don't care about decor or service - both are just fine, by the way - but the food is great.  Try anything.  Try everything.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Christopher B.

description: Where to start...it recently (in the last year) went through a modest little makeover of the facade and brick outside and may have under gone a management change also??  This place is a diamond in the rough to have on Balboa.  Many thanks to the owners/staff who run the place now.  Curteous, quick and thoughful and with interesting menu and nice paper Chinese tales of dumpling and soup on the walls.  It is a Village House type simplicity replete with the classic linoleum and fluorescent lighting sf is known for :)).  House made Xiao Long Bao is ordered almost every time.  Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.  Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).  The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.  Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.  The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.  Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite
author: Christopher H.

description: We get there for early dinner tonight. The place is not big and clean enough. The waiter is very polite and a little bit busy. Look like the restaurant is operate by a small family. They just updated and changed the menu to a very nice looking one. We like the food there. Look good and taste good. Price is just right. I see many people order food to-go.
author: Kwok L.

description:
Homemade and so good! We ate here tonight (dine-in, not take-out). The gal who served us (young gal with glasses) was really nice and attentive and service was great. We had the following dishes:

(1) braised beef noodle soup. I really loved the broth. It's not as salty as other restaurants which I like. Tons of flavor, the noodles were chewy and fresh, and the beef was pretty lean and so tender! 

(2) pork and shrimp and chive dumplings. So good! And the meat is already seasoned perfectly so I wouldn't recommend dipping these in soy sauce or any kind of sauce, just eat them plain. The wrapper was homemade and fresh. 

(3) xlb. Another winner! Delicate light and full of flavorful soup, just how good xlb should be. 

(4) green onion pancakes. Crispy fried on the outside, doughy and chewy on the inside, just delicious. 

(5) steamed red bean bun. This was the only disappointing dish, I wouldn't recommend this one. 

Will definitely go back!
author: A L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since I loved the previous dim sum place that was at this location. When we couldn't find parking for Hong Kong Lounge, we decided to come home and walk a block to Village House. It was, in a word, disappointing. The dumplings were very doughy and bland. The fillings were also pretty tasteless. I was also really craving a baked BBQ pork bun--a staple in dim sum--and they didn't have any! 

I was heartened, though, they they do in fact take credit cards, despite the "cash only" sign on the window. 

I might be willing to try again considering this is a neighborhood place and I like supporting small businesses in my hood. But I won't have high hopes. Sigh.
author: Amy B.

description:
After the previous (and my favorite) dim sum place at this location closed, I was fairly apprehensive about Village House when it opened. When I first walked in I was pleasantly surprised to find that they make all their dim sum fresh, right up front for everyone to see. The atmosphere of the place is nice as well. It's small, quiet, clean and pleasantly decorated. The staff is courteous and more than willing to answer any questions you may have. The size of the menu is decent for a place like this, but what's on the menu is fairly uninspired. There isn't much you won't find at any other generic Chinese-American restaurant. The real question is... is the food any good? 

I have been to Village House half a dozen times over the span of a few weeks to try and get a sense of quality and consistency. Unfortunately, they are one of the most inconsistent restaurants I have ever experienced. The dim sum has ranged from absolutely outstanding to a doughy, under-seasoned mess. the chicken dumpling with green chives is the only one that really blew my mind. The potstickers, which are typically one of my favorite dishes, were a total disappointment. They charge $5.95 for 4 doughy, flavorless pockets of disappointment. I can go to any number of other dim sum places and get 3 for around $2. The spicy dumplings, which were recommended to me as their most popular dish tasted okay, but made me feel ill later that day. Also, more than one my dishes were swimming in oil, which somewhat ruined it for me. Out of curiosity I tried the Chinese hamburger. It's simple and delicious. I just wish it had more filling. I would recommend it as a late-afternoon snack to anyone walking by looking for a quick bite to eat. My biggest complaint about this place isn't actually about the quality of the food it's the fact that everything is made to order, which in this case is actually a detriment to their business model. Dim sum restaurants are supposed to be fast and have small portioned, good quality dumplings at affordable prices. Village House doesn't really offer that. The prices are too high for the quality of food they provide and because everything is made to order, you have to wait a minimum of 10 minutes for even a single order of dim sum. I haven't tried any of their soups yet and I have seen quite a few people ordering it when they eat in the restaurant. They look quite good and I look forward to trying them. Although my experiences with Village House have not been the best so far, I will go again to try different things and see if their consistency improves. 

Overall I believe Village House has the potential to be a great, local dim sum place, but at this point I wouldn't recommend ordering any of the actual dumplings. It is a good place to bring a date for a small meal before seeing a movie at the theater down the street. It's a quiet and pleasant experience, even if the food is subpar.
author: Chris S.

description: The ONLY thing that saved this Review is the Potstickers.  We ordered food for delivery. We waited One Hour and 30 Minutes for Cold Food. and I had to Call to see where my order was.  Only after my call did the food arrive - 30 minutes later... When they arrived the food was Cold.  The steamed bbq pork buns were hard as a rock, we could not eat these as they were hard, cold and the filling was DRY as Hay...   We ended up eating the Potstickers for dinner since the other food we ordered was not edible.   Next time, just order potstickers.
author: Luba P.

description: Owners are very friendly and the portions are pretty good for the price. Most dishes were right around $10. We went there during lunchtime and ordered Mongolian lamb and beef, beef chow mein, "Chinese hamburger" (jia mo) with a soup. The selection is nothing extraordinary but the experience was quite satisfying.
author: Kit R.

description:
I happened to have walked by a shop window on Balboa where I noticed a woman inside very carefully wrapping dough around pot sticker filling.  Once I was inside, I was charmed by a two-year old happily being doted upon by the people working there.  How could I resist?  It was like coming inside a family's home.  I was coming from a place of not being quite sure what to order. I placed myself at the cashier's mercy.  She made a recommendation and I simply went along.  They brought me tea which a gentleman kept checking several times to make sure it was still warm.  (Could this gentleman be the child's grandfather)?  When the food came it was amazing.  It was spicy lamb that was out of this world.  When the cashier noticed I was enjoying my meal she gave me a big smile and "thumb's up!".  The food was so good that I ordered a "Flaming spicy lamb" dish to take home to my wife. She had it the next day and loved it as well.
I would recommend Village House to anyone who would enjoy the feeling of walking into a family's kitchen and feeling right at home.  They were very gracious and the food was excellent in being both savory and spicy.  This is proof that we are so fortunate to live in a City that has a rich diversity of cultures that allow us to enjoy a very special restaurant as Village House.  (The cashier knew I was going to be back)!
author: Leo I.

description:
I am very excited to see this place open in my neighborhood, although I did go to Jook Time (the previous Cantonese/Dim Sum restaurant) a lot. The sitting area is bigger, and food is more stewed,  boiled and steamed than deep fried. You can see ladies making dumplings or buns out in the front. 

If you want some homemade dumplings, steamed buns, potsticker, pancakes, and noodle soup, here is the place to go. It's northern style Chinese food (Hebei). 

They are very generous on their portions. The broth of the noodles taste so yummy and healthy. They also offer lunch boxes and their price is very good. 

I havent tried their stir-fried dishes yet, but i am eyeing on the Xinjiang Style Spicy Chicken over Noodles. 

So far my favorites are:
-Dumplings
-Beef pancake
-Beef noodles soup
-Dumpling noodle soup
author: Yuan Z.

description: Had the Beef Tendon Noodle Soup to go. It was not a good experience. There was not a single piece of tendon in there. What I did find were thick slices of very dry, under-seasoned beef in a greasy soup. And it's definitely overpriced at $9.95.
author: David W.

description: Came here with the family and tried a bunch of stuff. Only items that I like are the green onion pancakes and the beef braised noodle soup. They make the noodles themselves and the texture is spot on. The soup is good and beef is tender. The rest wasn't bad, but nothing to rave about.
author: Karen H.

description: Tonight was the first time that I ordered from this restaurant. I'm glad I found them. The delivery was quite fast and all of the food was great. This place has all of the classic American Chinese dishes that a white guy like myself would expect to see on the menu plus many different options that I have never seen before. The names of the dishes seemed a little misleading and the dishes weren't quite what I was expecting but I was definitely pleasantly surprised when I tried them. Will be ordering again.
author: Lane G.

description:
The food was Ok, the red bun bean and pork bun were yummy.
But! The black bean sauce noodles gave me food poisoning. I'd SERIOUSLY rethink about going here. I feel terrible after eating that.
author: Marissa S.

description: We came here looking for some dishes to bring to my aunt's house for dinner.  The selection was slim, so we ordered some Chow Mein and some Chow Fun.  I was not very impressed with the food.  Not sure if i will be back...
author: Antonia M.

description: Just not good. Ordered thru Postmates and not only was there hair in my dumpling soup, I received pork & shrimp dumplings when I ordered shrimp (I don't eat pork). Called to get the right order and was told there's nothing wrong with mine... Usually when a dish is just labeled "shrimp" it doesn't include other meat in my experience. Won't be ordering here again as there are soooo many better places around here
author: Andrea R.

description: The family who runs the restaurant were very sweet and helpful. And the food was delish. You can tell that they make all there own dumplings. Very tender and flavorful.
author: Rebecca N.

description: Tasty food, friendly place. Ordered pork fried rice, pork chow mein, garlic spinach. Walnut prawns and pork/shrimp dumplings were our fav!!
author: Johanna-Joy G.

description: Village house is an underrated local spot in the Richmond. Noodle texture is the #1 thing I am concerned with at noodle/dumpling restaurants. In terms of noodle texture, I'd give this place 8/10. Chewy noodles and good sour cabbage fish soup! I'm about to be a regular at this spot.
author: Jessica L.

description: I love the dumpling and noodle because they're all handmade . It really healthy and good quality for me ,even for everyone . I ate lamb dumpling and braised beef noodle soup . It taste very good . I'm going to try different food next time .
author: Sisi W.

description: Love the Village House! My favorite items are the braised tofu, green scallion pancakes and spicy dumplings. So goof!
author: David A.

description: Came here for the first time and loved it! The bean source noodle and dumpling are awesome! Very authentic Beijing food. Will definitely come here next time!
author: Danning C.

description: Definitely one of my favorite places to eat in Richmond district! Good food for a good price!
author: bryan c.

description: Village House has incredibly decently authentic chinese food, it reminds me of home whenever I'm feeling cozy and wanting comfort food. Delivery service was very nice, the driver was nice and down to earth.
author: Zilu G.

description: We ordered delivery: the hot and sour soup, beef chow fun, and the hot and sweet chicken wings. Highly recommend the hot and sour soup and the rest of the food but the soup made an impression. Big plus to the fact the food was still hot when delivered. We also ordered the xiao long bao (hope I spelled it right). I was hoping to order some dim sum but it was not on the online menu.
author: Maria R.

description: I tried dumplings all over San Francisco.  This place by far has the best!!  Why? Because if you eat them at the restaurant they never freeze the dumplings.  They make it as you order.   I have not eat dumplings anywhere else since I found this place.   Koi place xiaolungbao is a joke. Try them here and you will know.
author: juAn L.

description:
I was a huge fan of Jook Time for their cheap, huge selection of dim sum so I was really sad to see it go. I was very wary when I saw a much bigger seating selection while Village House was remodeling, worried that it wouldn't have dim sum options and was purely a sit down place. However, it's looking like they're doing ready to go dim sum, at least a bit! It's definitely more of a sit down place and their ready made food is a little lacking in selection, but it's there and I'm hoping they expand on it more. 

Regardless, I've been there a couple times now and it's been pretty good! I was again worried that it would be a copycat of Shanghai Dumpling King across the street, but their menu is different enough that it works on its own. So far I've tried the chinese hamburger, ready made and fresh made pork dumplings, ready made fried rice, green onion pancake and beef pancake. The chinese hamburger was a little dry, but the flavor was definitely there! It's a bit spicy too. I feel like the buns were what was making it dry, as they were a bit thick and dense. I wasn't a huge fan of the ready made pork dumplings. They felt a bit bland to me, but somehow the ones I ordered that were made fresh were much better. Perhaps it was because they were hot? When I ordered the green onion pancake I thought it would be the usual fried dough with green onions, but this was instead a fried dough filled with fresh veggies and green onion! It was -very- good and you get a lot. I think bits of the dough weren't cooked completely, but I honestly didn't mind in the slightest. I love the very slightly underdone texture. The premade fried rice was very bland but I liked the addition of pineapple to it. I just threw in a bit of salt when I got home and it was better. The beef pancake has to be my favorite so far, though. It's the same kind of green onion pancake dough but wrapped almost crepe style around green onion, various green veggies, beef, cilantro and a really tasty sauce. 

Pricewise it's pretty standard. Prices range between $2.50-$10. With how downhill Shanghai Dumpling King has been feeling, it's nice to have a good lunch option for a similar price point. 

They don't have any music playing, but everyone is very friendly and the wait times for food aren't super long! I've only ever done take out, but I'd like to sit down at some point and see how it goes. Definitely needs music, though. It was pretty quiet in there.  

Overall I definitely recommend it! I'm knocking off a star for the fairly bland premade food, but I have high hopes for the rest of the menu!
author: Benny G.

description: My girlfriend and I recently bought takeout from here and our experience was unpleasant. The estimated wait time was 15 minutes for our food and I expected so as we ordered food at 3:15 in the afternoon but our actual wait time was 30+ minutes. The food is only okay in terms of Chinese food, prices are a bit steep IMO and the portions are not as large as other competitors in the area. Personally not a fan.
author: Brian H.

description: One of the best places for dumplings .better than dumpling king across the street and no line. They are family owned and the chef sometimes comes out to talk with you about his food. I get takeout here all the time since I lived nearby
author: Micmic W.

description: We really like this place. Friendly service and good food. We really love the braised tofu ... tofu is perfect. Otherwise - we are dumpling fans and we always have their frozen dumplings in our freezer (awesome that they sell these) just in case we need to eat some and we are too lazy to leave the house
author: leslie y.

description: Loved the taste. Especially the Spicy Dumplings. The souse tastes just as same as the original souse in SiChuan, China. And I love the Dry Fried Chicken Wings too. The wings are really juicy and mouthwatering!  I give five stars for this Chinese restaurant, because of the professional chefs and great service. Village House made me feel like I was back to home. I love it!
author: Peng L.

description: Excellent dumplings. The food here was fantastic, service very friendly, and very reasonably priced. Would definitely return.
author: sara s.

description:
Village house is a pretty clean and small restaurant. This place used be Dim Sum take out place which I liked better.

Now to the food. They served me cold dumplings which was warm on the outside and frozen on the inside. I informed the lady that works the front which she apologized and said she would bring out a new batch. Well it was not a new batch it was the same she brought out earlier and just warmed it up. Overall the flavor is bland with all their other food on the menu that I ordered. Will not be going back. Save yourself some money and go to Dumpling King across the street.
author: Jason C.

description: Ordered takeout from here. First, I ordered three items but we only received two of the three items. The two items took too long that we weren't able to wait and reorder the third item and just decided to bring the two items home. One item we ordered was called Crispy Pot Pancake for $6.95. I posted a picture of this in the photo section. It tasted so disappointingly bland that we probably would have been better off ordering Green Pancake that is two dollars less. The Pork and Shrimp dumpling was yummy enough hence the two stars.
author: Marilyn O.

description: So disappointed with the Village House.  The food offerings were terrible.  The cost ridiculous for tasteless, rubbery food.  I would not recommend this place unless it is the only choice you have, but then if the corner store is open I'd rather go there to buy some chips.
author: Natalie A.
